Here we go! Today is the day we are launching Interop 2023. You can read about *all* the details on the WebKit Blog at https://webkit.org/blog/13706/interop-2023/

Interop 2023 continues 7 focus areas from last year (while retiring 8) and adds 18 new areas. We are excited to see the engineering teams behind Chrome/Edge, Firefox and Safari all strive to pass as many tests as possible — tests that check to see how close implementations are to the web standards that define those technologies.

Was feeling like my #quirkyclock was spinning out of control with feature bloat, so rid of the background color, dots, and hands. From here on out, I’m gonna be more judicious about having a good reason for every tiny element I add, and keep a copy of each clock as it continues to evolve. It’s kinda fun taking such a tiny little product so seriously.

V1: https://busterbenson.com/clock

V2: https://busterbenson.com/clock2

title: Netlify Acquires Gatsby Inc. to Accelerate Adoption of Composable Web Architectures

last_post.content:
I took a peep over at twitter to see what people there were saying about this news:

https://www.netlify.com/press/netlify-acquires-gatsby-inc-to-accelerate-adoption-of-composable-web-architectures/

A big misconception I'm seeing is that Netlify wanted to *own* a react-based framework and join that club, leading to lock-in.

The opposite is true. Netlify already support other open-source frameworks without lock-in or roadmap ownership. Expect that.

And Gatsby is wayyyy bigger than Gatsby.js. ☁️

title: New Pentagon Rules Keep Many Military Court Records Secret

last_post.content:
A 2016 law says military court records must be transparent.

But new Pentagon rules grant access only *after* a trial. Plus they exclude:
▪️ transcripts/recordings
▪️ exhibits
▪️ preliminary hearing documents

So much for open records.
(Worth noting: @propublica is suing the Navy over its withholding of documents.)
https://www.propublica.org/article/navy-records-defense-department-bonhomme

Vetting others' research is the cornerstone of peer-reviewed science...yet most aren't given any formal training on how to do this.

Poor-quality reviewer feedback can derail a paper rather than improve it, collectively wasting everyone's time.

A recent paper explores this problem and proposes using a peer-review process akin to @eLife's model: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tma.2023.01.002
h/t @bahar

title: Cultivation – Recovery Hub for American Women Writers

last_post.content:
The Recovery Hub for American Women Writers seeks applications for the next round of project cultivation. Projects eligible for support include digital editions of letters, books, short fiction, and other texts as well as experimental projects that explore mapping, visualization, and other content-rich methods. Awarded practitioners will receive a $2,000 stipend to support their work on the project, in addition to technical help. Stipends may be used to help buy out time, support student workers, or offset travel or technical costs.

https://recoveryhub.siue.edu/cultivation/

Priority deadline: February 28, 2023

I am happy to answer any questions you may have!

#recovery #DigitalHumanities #ProjectCultivation #WomenWriters #DigitalEditions

title: Migrating Male Birds Race Ahead to Keep Up with Spring’s Early Arrival

last_post.content:
#Climate #change-driven earlier springs mean #migrating #birds return to their breeding ranges earlier. But #male birds from a number of species are arriving earlier and earlier than #females.

This could mean that arrival feeding, #reproduction, and foraging for food for the young also end up out-of-sync.

Climate change effects are everywhere, and even seemingly small but consistent temperature shifts can be amplified in #complex #ecological #systems.

See: https://www.audubon.org/news/migrating-male-birds-race-ahead-keep-springs-early-arrival

If you’ve been an author or a reviewer on a #RegisteredReport consider giving feedback about your experience here: https://registeredreports.cardiff.ac.uk/feedback/home/

It’s important to evaluate initiatives like RRs to see how they’re working in practice and to incentivise journals to make the RR process optimal, and your feedback as either a reviewer or author will help that evaluation. Not to mention you’ll be helping @benmeg with his PhD!

I just did it and it took me <5 minutes.

Gotta give posthumous flowers to Jerry Lawson, the man who created the first video game console w/interchangeable cartridges.

It was a watershed moment for gaming. As this USA Today article notes, it was "the foundation for today's global video game market."

In his honor, there's a Lawson exhibit on permanent display at The World Video Game Hall of Fame at The Strong National Museum of Play in Rochester, NY

title: Anti-intellectualism amid the COVID-19 pandemic: The discursive elements and sources of anti-Fauci tweets - Yingying Chen, Jacob Long, Jungmi Jun, Sei-Hill Kim, Ali Zain, Colin Piacentine, 2023

last_post.content:
New paper: In an analysis of 7960 tweets attacking #AnthonyFauci, Chen et al identify 3 themes:

1️⃣ 23% of tweets: people-scientist antagonism (conflict of “ordinary” people vs “elitist” science)
2️⃣ 40%: delegitimizing scientists’ motivation (scientists are allegedly corrupt)
3️⃣ 18%: delegitimizing scientists’ knowledge (evidence allegedly faulty)

Great to see #css methods applied to our concept of #science-related #populism @mss7676

I learned about this company last year from one of my students: https://www.causalens.com/

Their goal is to build #AI that can detect causal mechanisms in large datasets (ie move from correlation to causation).

On one hand, I want to say "this is absurd." Bc on one level that's all there is to it. On the other, it does raise interesting questions within & beyond political epistemology. Questions about meaning construction & narrative power especially interest me.

It's 70 years since the devastating #NorthSeaFloods of 1953. Their impact in the Netherlands + Belgium is pretty well known, but I'm often surprised how little people in the UK are aware of the history.
Around 500 people in total lost their lives, including 300 on land in England when #CanveyIsland was flooded. The rest were lost at sea from ferry + fishing boats.

As a result the #ThamesBarrage + #HumberBarrage were built.

#CoastalFlooding #StormSurge

title: Open Sourcing SimCity, by Chaim Gingold - Don Hopkins - Medium

last_post.content:
although now long forgotten as a historical curio of 2000s web idealism, the OLPC "One Laptop Per Child" project attempted to produce a low-cost, high-reliability laptop suitable for kids in low-income environments.

one of the upshots of the program was that SimCity was open-sourced for the OLPC XO-1 computer, and it was included on every machine. this little article by don hopkins does a great job of tracing its history through Sun Microsystems.

google.com -> paypal.verylegit.link/8U70*m[uO409index.apk.pem.dmg
verylegit.link -> click.here.to.get.

In new study w @richardneher we estimate effects of mutations to all SARSCoV2 proteins: https://biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.01.30.526314v1

Demonstrates new way to determine effects of mutations in era of millions of genomes.

As background, knowing effect of each individual SARSCoV2 mutation is valuable for:

1⃣designing drugs that won’t be easily escaped,

2⃣interpreting new mutations seen during viral surveillance,

3⃣understanding function/mechanism of viral proteins.

title: What Is COVID Actually Doing to Our Immune Systems?

last_post.content:
”We’re not seeing evidence that this one virus has changed our immune system’s ability to keep us healthy on a large scale. There are 7 billion people on the planet who are doing fairly well. And we’re not seeing opportunistic infections, we’re not seeing huge increases in cancers …, we’re just not seeing the kinds of things that we saw in other settings where the immune system was compromised…”

https://slate.com/technology/2023/01/immunity-covid-research-airborne-aids-debunk.html

Inspired by the blog post linked below, I added #git diff support for Org files. This will show the heading title in the corresponding @@ block for each hunk.

So the .gitattributes entry is simply:

*.org diff=org

The .gitconfig block is:

[diff "org"]
xfuncname="^\\*+ +(.*)$"

Read the whole blog post for the proper setup, it will show you how to do something similar for definitions in Common #Lisp or #Emacs Lisp.

https://www.n16f.net/blog/improving-git-diffs-for-lisp/

title: Who Is Pauli Murray? — Pauli Murray Center

last_post.content:
Pauli Murray was a lawyer, scholar, activist, poet & priest. A civil rights leader, their activism set the stage for the desegregation of US schools.

Murray co-founded the National Organization for Women. Ruth Bader Ginsburg credited them for the idea that the 14th amendment could win equality for women.

Murray changed history & led battles for racial & gender equality. S/he has too many accomplishments to list, but we should celebrate their contributions. https://www.paulimurraycenter.com/who-is-pauli #history

After an email from Flourish touting their new interactive Marimekko chart premium template, I had to see how to create a #dataviz like that in :rstats: ! @dqn has a great step-by-step guide using ggplot2 and ggiraph:
https://dqn.website/post/interactive-mekko-charts-in-r/

If you've never used the {ggiraph} #rstats 📦, it's an easy way to create interactive charts from your #ggplot2 plots.
My #ggiraph tutorial:
https://www.infoworld.com/article/3626911/easy-interactive-ggplot-graphs-in-r-with-ggiraph.html
10-minute video: https://youtu.be/12QaZp1FokU
